newsitem.title: CHINA: China says Guatemala ruins basis of cooperation.
newsitem.headline: China says Guatemala ruins basis of cooperation.

text.p: China said on Thursday that Guatemala's ties with Taiwan had destroyed any basis for cooperation from Beijing in the United Nations.

Guatemala's invitation to Taiwan's Foreign Ministry to attend the December 29 signing of a peace treaty that ended 36 years of civil war had hurt the feelings of the Chinese people, Foreign Ministry spokesman Shen Guofang told a news briefing.
"This action... has destroyed the political basis for cooperation between Guatemala and China within the United Nations," Shen said.
Shen stopped short of saying Beijing would veto a proposed U.N. peace-keeping mission to monitor the end of Guatemala's guerrilla war but accused Guatemala of hypocrisy in its dealings with Beijing.
"The Guatemalan authorities not only... do things that harm China's sovereignty and territorial integrity, but also ask for China's cooperation in the U.N. Security Council," Shen said.

China has withheld support for a United Nations' Security Council resolution to send 155 U.N. peace-keepers to Guatemala because of that country's close ties with Taiwan, which Beijing views as a rebel province.

Diplomats have said they believe Beijing will not veto the measure but is trying to wring some concessions from Guatemala -- perhaps a high-level visit and an eventual trade mission to slowly wean the Central American country from Taiwan.
Guatemala has vowed to maintain official relations with Taiwan despite the heavy pressure from China.
Taiwan bestows considerable economic aid on Guatemala, one of less than 30 mostly small, impoverished states in Central America and Africa that recognise Taipei instead of Beijing.
China and Taiwan have been bitter political rivals since the two were separated at the end of the Chinese civil war in 1949.
Beijing has sought to push Taipei into diplomatic isolation in its quest to bring the island under communist control.
